Take-home Exercise 2: DataVis Makeover

DataVis Makeover of Take-home Exercise 1

Author

Victoria Neo

Published

February 1, 2024

Modified

February 6, 2024

1 Setting the scene

1.1 The Task

In this take-home exercise, you are required to:

  • select one of the Take-home Exercise 1 prepared by your classmate,

  • critic the submission in terms of clarity and aesthetics,

  • prepare a sketch for the alternative design by using the data visualisation design principles and best practices you had learned in Lesson 1 and 2, and

  • remake the original design by using ggplot2, ggplot2 extensions and tidyverse packages.

Remember Take-home Exercise 1

The 2022 Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) data was released on December 5, 2022. PISA global education survey every three years to assess the education systems worldwide through testing 15 year old students in the subjects of mathematics, reading, and science.

In this take-home exercise, you are required to use appropriate Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) methods and ggplot2 functions to reveal:

  • the distribution of Singapore students‚Äô performance in mathematics, reading, and science, and

  • the relationship between these performances with schools, gender and socioeconomic status (SES) of the students.

1.2 Getting Started

1.2.1 Installing R packages and loading the dataset

The code chunk below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if the necessary packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

code block 
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse, kableExtra,
               haven, dplyr,
               ggdist, ggridges,
               colorspace, ggpmisc)

The code chunk below reads the .rds file that contains cleaned data about students from Singapore.

code block 
cleaned_data <-
  read_rds("data/cleaned_studata.rds")

2 Data Visualisations Makeover

The data visualisations were taken from here. I will be doing the makeover according to my favourite ggtheme theme_fivethirtyeight()

2.1 Distribution Across Three Subjects - Mathematics, Reading and Science

The author stated:

We will now do the plot for each respective subject. We will be doing a histogram to show the distribution across three subjects. The figure in the tabset below displays a composite of three histograms, seamlessly created using patchwork. This is specifically designed for merging separate ggplot2 graphs into a unified figure. The red dotted line indicates the mean.

He later went on to conclude:

The histogram presented above offers a visual representation of the distribution of scores across three academic subjects: MATHEMATICS, READING and SCIENCE. The distribution pattern observed for each subject strongly aligns with the characteristics of a normal distribution (bold my own).


A normal distribution is characterised by a symmetrical bell-shaped curve, with the majority of data points clustering around the mean and gradually tapering off towards the extremes. In the context of academic performance, this implies that a significant proportion of students scored close to the average, while fewer students achieved scores either significantly above or below the mean.

2.1.1 Own Thoughts

One key issue I want to highlight is the author‚Äôs conclusion that the distributions of all three scores are normal. My own personal conclusion were the distributions were left-skewed.

Visual Challenges

  • The visualisations did not clearly represent if the distributions were normal or left-skewed.

2.1.2 Critique: Clarity and Aesthetics

This uncertainty could be due to how the data was visualised. By using the principles from A Layered Grammar of Graphics,

Level 7: Theme (Colour | Space)

  • Aesthetics

    • The blue and red, while to provide contrast, does not blend well with the other colours.
    • Grid lines are soft and not distracting.

  • Clarity

    • The patchwork neatly puts all the plots in one diagram but the dimensions are not equally spaced for each plot (it seems that Science scores are given more weightage than the rest).

Level 7: Theme (Text)

  • Aesthetics

    • There is too much cluttered text: the titles and axes labels are not well placed.
    • count is not placed vertically: may not be necessary

  • Clarity

    • There is no overall main title or lead-in to provide a context .e.g. the purpose and the story of the data visualisation.

    • The titles are repeated e.g. Math scores and Mathematics.

    • The axes are not well-labelled e.g. Mathematics as the x-axis.

    • There is no data source caption included.

Level 6: Coordinates | Level 5: Statistics | Level 3: Geometries | Level 2: Aesthetics

  • Clarity

    • The max labelled counts on the x-axis for the three plots are not consistent - 800 for Mathematics vs 750 for Reading and Science.

    • The units of the y-axis for the three plots are not consistent - Math is 400, 600, 800 vs 200, 400, 600 and 800 for Reading and Science; and Science‚Äôs x-axis starts at 200 while the rest appears to start at 0.

    • The reference line (the mean) was very important for readability but still failed to fully convey if it was a normal or left-skewed distribution.

2.1.3 Sketch

These are my proposed main changes:

A well-crafted title and subtitle to provide context.

Add a median line together with the mean to clearly portray skewness.

Add a probability density plot to clearly visualise the distribution.

Standardise the axes to improve comparability and interpretability.

Put the three plots side-by-side to improve readability.

2.1.4 Makeover

The code chunk below prepares the individual histogram plots for each subject.

  • Mathematics
  • Reading
  • Science
code block 
math <- ggplot(data = cleaned_data, aes(x = MATH)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), bins = 20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25", 
                 fill = "grey90",
                 linewidth = 0.3) +
  geom_density(linewidth = 0.2) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 0.0045))  +
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(MATH), median_score = median(MATH)),
             aes(xintercept = median_score), color = "#008FD5", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(MATH), median_score = median(MATH)),
             aes(x = median_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Median:", round(median_score, 0))),
             color = "#008FD5", vjust = 1, hjust = -0.55, size = 3) +
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(MATH), median_score = median(MATH)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_score), color = "#77AB43", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(MATH), median_score = median(MATH)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "#77AB43", vjust = 1, hjust = 0.55, size = 3) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100)) +
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Math scores') 
math
code block 
read <- ggplot(data=cleaned_data, 
             aes(x= READ)) +
geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), bins = 20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25", 
                 fill = "grey90",
                 linewidth = 0.3) +
  geom_density(linewidth = 0.2) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 0.0045))  +
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ), median_score = median(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = median_score), color = "#008FD5", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ), median_score = median(READ)),
             aes(x = median_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Median:", round(median_score, 0))),
             color = "#008FD5", vjust = 1, hjust = -0.55, size = 3) +
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ), median_score = median(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_score), color = "#77AB43", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ), median_score = median(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "#77AB43", vjust = 1, hjust = 0.55, size = 3) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100)) +
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Reading scores') 
read
code block 
sci <- ggplot(data=cleaned_data, 
             aes(x= SCIENCE)) +
geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), bins = 20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25", 
                 fill = "grey90",
                 linewidth = 0.3) +
  geom_density(linewidth = 0.2) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 0.0045))  +
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(SCIENCE), median_score = median(SCIENCE)),
             aes(xintercept = median_score), color = "#008FD5", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(SCIENCE), median_score = median(SCIENCE)),
             aes(x = median_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Median:", round(median_score, 0))),
             color = "#008FD5", vjust = 1, hjust = -0.55, size = 3) +
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(SCIENCE), median_score = median(SCIENCE)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_score), color = "#77AB43", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(SCIENCE), median_score = median(SCIENCE)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "#77AB43", vjust = 1, hjust = 0.55, size = 3) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100)) +
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Science scores') 
sci

2.1.5 Final Product: Distribution of Math, Reading and Science scores

The code chunk below prepares the individual histogram plots for each subject as a composite figure.

code block 
patchwork <- math + read + sci
patchwork <- patchwork + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Singapore students score exceptionally well in Maths, Reading and Science.",
    subtitle = "More than 50% of students have scores higher than the mean across the three PISA subjects.",
    caption = "Data source: OECD PISA 2022",
    theme = theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 50))  
  )
patchwork & theme_fivethirtyeight(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor.x = element_line(linewidth = 0.2, linetype = 'solid', colour = "grey85"),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), axis.title=element_text(face = "bold", size=9))

2.2 Reading vs Mathematics

The author stated:

The scatterplot‚Ä¶ illustrates a positive correlation between reading and mathematics values. As the reading values increase, so do the corresponding mathematics values. This relationship is further emphasised by the upward trend observed in the best fit line. The consistent increase in one variable is mirrored by a proportional increase in the other. In light of these findings, it can be confidently asserted that a positive connection exists, suggesting that engaging in reading contributes to enhanced performance in mathematics among students (bold my own).

2.2.1 Own Thoughts

  1. The author‚Äôs intention of this data visualisation is a little confusing to me - why does the author only focus on one data visualisation with X = Reading and Y = Mathematics?

  1. Bearing in mind that the plot intends to visualise the relationship between two continuous variables, I also automatically thought of the scatterplot. However, while it does visualise the relationship, the data visualisation does not seem intuitive, despite the presence of the linear model line.

Visual Challenges

  • How can we visually tease out the relationship of reading on the other subjects and vice versa?

  • The visualisation is messy due to overplotting - is there a better way to visualise the relationship between two continuous variables?

  • How can we improve the identification of correlation in a scatterplot?

2.2.2 Critique: Clarity and Aesthetics

By using the principles from A Layered Grammar of Graphics,

Level 7: Theme (Colour | Space)

  • Aesthetics

    • The choice of black and blue provided a nice contrast.
    • Grid lines are soft and not distracting.

  • Clarity

    • It was confusing to use only one data visualisation on two subjects to tease out the relationship between subjects.

Level 7: Theme (Text)

  • Aesthetics

    • Axes are well-labelled so we can tease out any causal relationship between Reading and Mathematics.

  • Clarity

    • There is no overall main title or lead-in to provide a context .e.g. the purpose and the story of the data visualisation.

    • There is no data source caption included.

Level 6: Coordinates | Level 5: Statistics | Level 3: Geometries | Level 2: Aesthetics

  • Aesthetics

    • Overplotting - the mass of points from each student makes the chart messy and confusing (especially the dark mass in the centre of the reference line).

  • Clarity

    • The scales on the x-axis and y-axis are consistent - 800 for Mathematics and Reading scores.

    • Clearly visualised relationship between Reading and Mathematics scores with the use of a straight reference line - linear model.

2.2.3 Sketch

These are my proposed main changes:

A well-crafted title and subtitle to provide context.

Explore four different ways (refer to section below) to address overplotting in the scatterplot.

Add regression line coefficients to the lm reference line.

Create 2 more different data visualisations together to check which subjects had relationships with each other e.g. Reading vs Science.

Put the plots side-by-side to improve comparability.

Improving overplotting in scatterplots

According to A Complete Guide to Scatter Plots,

Overplotting is the case where data points overlap to a degree where we have difficulty seeing relationships between points and variables. It can be difficult to tell how densely-packed data points are when many of them are in a small area.

There are a few common ways to alleviate this issue. One alternative is to sample only a subset of data points: a random selection of points should still give the general idea of the patterns in the full data. We can also change the form of the dots, adding transparency to allow for overlaps to be visible, or reducing point size so that fewer overlaps occur. As a third option, we might even choose a different chart type like the heatmap, where color indicates the number of points in each bin. Heatmaps in this use case are also known as 2-d histograms.

The code chunk below shows four different recommended ways to address overplotting.

Plot 1 with sampled data (sample = 400)

code block 
# Set the seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)

# Randomly select a sample of about 500 students
sampled_data <- cleaned_data %>% sample_n(400)

# Create the scatterplot with the sampled data
samplescatter <- ggplot(sampled_data, aes(x = READ, y = MATH)) +  
  geom_point() +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2"))) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                      minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))
samplescatter

Plot 2 with transparency (alpha = 0.03)

code block 
transscatter <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=MATH) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2"))) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))

transscatter

Plot 3 with hexagon binning (bins = 25)

code block 
hexscatter <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=MATH) ) +
  geom_hex(bins = 25, color = "white", alpha = 0.6) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low="#008FD5",high="black")+
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2"))) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "black", alpha = 0.4)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))

hexscatter

Plot 4 with 2D Histogram (bins = 25)

code block 
twodscatter <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=MATH) ) +
  geom_bin2d(bins = 25, color = "white",alpha = 0.6) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low="#008FD5",high="black")+
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2"))) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "black", alpha = 0.4)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))
 
twodscatter

In the end, Plot 2 seemed the most aesthetically pleasing - since the scatterplot‚Äôs intention is to convey that there is a correlation between Reading and Math scores, and given that most scores cluster in the middle of the cloud, it appeared that binning or gradient colours made it messier.

2.2.4 Makeover

The code chunk below prepares the individual histogram plots for each subject.

  • Reading vs Mathematics
  • Reading vs Science
  • Mathematics vs Science
code block 
# Calculate midpoints
mean_math <- mean(cleaned_data$MATH)

readvsmath <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=MATH) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2")), hjust = -0.45, vjust = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))  +
 ylab('Math Scores') + xlab('Reading Scores') 

readvsmath
code block 
readvssci <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=SCIENCE) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2")), hjust = -0.51, vjust = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))   +
 ylab('Science Scores') + xlab('Reading Scores') 
readvssci
code block 
mathvssci <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=MATH, y=SCIENCE) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2")), hjust = -0.42, vjust = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))   +
 ylab('Science Scores') + xlab('Math Scores') 
mathvssci

2.2.5 Final Product: The relationships between Math, Reading and Science scores

The code chunk below prepares the individual scatterplots for subject pairwise comparison as a composite figure.

code block 
patchwork <- readvsmath + readvssci + mathvssci
patchwork <- patchwork + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "The higher you score in one subject, the more likely you will score as well as in the other subjects.",
    subtitle = "Strong positive linear relationships between Math, Reading and Science scores.\nThis is especially true in Math and Science scores that have the strongest correlation.",
    caption = "Data source: OECD PISA 2022",
    theme = theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 50))  
  )
patchwork & theme_fivethirtyeight(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor.x = element_line(linewidth = 0.2, linetype = 'solid', colour = "grey85"),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), axis.title=element_text(face = "bold", size=9))

2.3 ‚ÄúReading‚Äù as our main focus

As mentioned in the previous section, the author is focusing on Reading scores as

[W]e assert that prioritising reading over mathematics is essential for enhanced performance in science learning.

Henceforth, our focus will be exclusively on reading, considering it as the primary driver for improved achievement in other subjects, including Mathematics and Science.

The author took this perspective because:

With reference to this research paper titled ‚ÄòReading matters more than mathematics in science learning: an analysis of the relationship between student achievement in reading, mathematics, and science‚Äô by Yuanze Zhu, the results revealed that proficiency in reading and mathematics strongly correlated with science achievement, with reading exerting a more substantial influence than mathematics.

The author built three different plots to uncover the relationship between Gender, Socioeconomic status (SES) and Schools; and Reading scores.

  • Gender
  • Socioeconomic status
  • Schools

A boxplot was used to visualise the differences in reading scores between females and males.

A scatterplot was used to derive any relationship between Reading scores and one‚Äôs socioeconomic status (SES).

A boxplot was used to visualise the differences in reading scores amongst the top 5 heavily represented schools (those who had the most students participating) in PISA.

2.3.1 Own Thoughts

  1. I find it confusing to have three separate plots - I think we can group all plots together as the common variable is Reading scores.

  2. I think the choice of using the top 5 heavily represented schools is not meaningful. Using the label ‚Äútop 5‚Äù is more traditionally associated with performance, rather than size of representation.

Visual Challenges

  • How can we visually tease out the relationship of the three independent variables on reading scores?

  • Boxplots limit our understanding on the shape of distribution, modality and skewness. How can we improve the readability of boxplots?

  • How can we improve SchoolIDs as a meaningful label and visually represent them?

As scatterplots have been critiqued and explored in the previous section of [2.2 Reading vs Mathematics], I will makeover the Reading scores vs ESCS in the same way, while flipping the X- and Y- axis.

2.3.2 Critique: Clarity and Aesthetics

In this section, I will be critiquing the use of boxplots to visually represent the relationships between Gender and Schools; and Reading scores. By using the principles from A Layered Grammar of Graphics,

Level 7: Theme (Colour | Space)

  • Aesthetics

    • The choice of black and grey was in line with previous data visualisations, providing consistency.

    • The choice of a red dot (mean) on black provided contrast, but the colours were jarring and not in line with a theme.

    • Grid lines are soft and not distracting.

  • Clarity

    • It was confusing to separate the plots - a story about effects on Reading scores would be better visualised if the plots were together.
Level 7: Theme (Text)

  • Aesthetics

    • Axes are well-labelled so we can immediately see what relationship (X- and Y- variables) the plot is visualising.

  • Clarity

    • There is no overall main title or lead-in to provide a context .e.g. the purpose and the story of the data visualisation.

    • There is no data source caption included.

    • CNTSCHID as a label is not meaningful.

and Level 6: Coordinates | Level 5: Statistics | Level 3: Geometries | Level 2: Aesthetics

  • Aesthetics

    • While boxplots give an excellent summary of the statistics, it looks very plain; especially since Males and Females have the same colour or all the schools presented have the same colour.

  • Clarity

    • Boxplots are good to compare between multiple groups e.g. between Males and Females and between schools.

    • The scales on the x-axis and y-axis are consistent - 800 for Reading scores, but may be too limited at 800 and result in outliers been cut off.

    • Clearly visualised some skewness with the use of the mean (red dot) and the outliers but hard to compare with other members of the group.

    • The order of groups is also confusing - in the Schools boxplot, there is no inherent order and thus difficult to compare between schools.

    • Boxplots do not allow us to observe the detailed shape of distribution of each groups - it was hard to see if the distribution was truly skewed.

    • The boxplots cannot be intuitively interpreted as they are not annotated with the sample population size, mean and median values.

    • SchoolIDs and their label CNTSCHID poorly represents the top 5 heavily represented schools in the sample. It does not allow for easy interpretability.

2.3.3 Sketch

These are my proposed main changes:

A well-crafted title and subtitle to provide context.

Explore different ways (refer to section below) to improve the simplicity of the boxplot.

Add text annotations such as the sample size to the boxplots.

Recreate CNTSCHID by using top 5 and bottom 5 performing schools in Reading scores.

Makeover the scatterplot of ESCS vs Reading scores using the above section‚Äôs scatterplot design.

Put the plots side-by-side to improve interpretability and readability for Reading scores.

Improving the visualisation of distribution in a boxplot

According to A Complete Guide to Scatter Plots, The Box Plot: A Simple but Informative Visualizationand 9  Visualising Distribution, there are four ways to improve the simplicity of the boxplot by using:t

  1. Notches in boxplots

Notches are used to show the most likely values expected for the median when the data represents a sample. When a comparison is made between groups, you can tell if the difference between medians are statistically significant based on if their ranges overlap. If any of the notch areas overlap, then we can‚Äôt say that the medians are statistically different; if they do not have overlap, then we can have good confidence that the true medians differ. A Complete Guide to Scatter Plots

  1. Violin plots

In a violin plot, each group‚Äôs distribution is indicated by a density curve. In a density curve, each data point does not fall into a single bin like in a histogram, but instead contributes a small volume of area to the total distribution. Violin plots are a compact way of comparing distributions between groups. Often, additional markings are added to the violin plot to also provide the standard box plot information, but this can make the resulting plot noisier to read. A Complete Guide to Scatter Plots

  1. Ridgeline plots

Ridgeline plot (sometimes called Joyplot) is a data visualisation technique for revealing the distribution of a numeric value for several groups. Distribution can be represented using histograms or density plots, all aligned to the same horizontal scale and presented with a slight overlap. 9  Visualising Distribution

  1. Raincloud plots

Raincloud Plot is a data visualisation techniques that produces a half-density to a distribution plot. It gets the name because the density plot is in the shape of a ‚Äúraincloud‚Äù. The raincloud (half-density) plot enhances the traditional box-plot by highlighting multiple modalities (an indicator that groups may exist). The boxplot does not show where densities are clustered, but the raincloud plot does! 9  Visualising Distribution

For Gender

The code chunk below shows four different recommended ways to improve the boxplot‚Äôs simplicity for two categories e.g. males and females.

Plot 1 with Notched Boxplots

code block 
gender_counts <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(count = n())

ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x = READ, y = GENDER, color = GENDER)) +  
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#c73824", "#0477bf")) +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun="mean",         
               colour ="black",     
               size=2) + 
     geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = -0.8, size = 3) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                      minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))  + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE)  +
  geom_text(data = gender_counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = GENDER, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000))

Plot 2 with Violin + Notched Boxplots

code block 
gender_counts <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(count = n())

ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x = READ, y = GENDER, color = GENDER)) +  
    geom_violin(aes(fill = GENDER), size = 0.6, alpha = 0.4, linewidth = 0) +
  geom_boxplot(width= 0.4, outlier.colour = "grey20", outlier.size = 1, 
               outlier.alpha = 0.3, notch = TRUE) +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun="mean",         
               colour ="black",        
               size=2) +  
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = -0.8, size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#c73824", "#0477bf")) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                      minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100)) + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE)  +
  geom_text(data = gender_counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = GENDER, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000))

Plot 3 with Ridgeline plots

code block 
pr <- ggplot(cleaned_data,
       aes(x = READ, 
           y = GENDER, 
           fill = factor(after_stat(quantile))
           )) +
  stat_density_ridges(
    geom = "density_ridges_gradient",
    calc_ecdf = TRUE, 
    quantiles = 4,
    quantile_lines = TRUE) +
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_fill_manual(name = "Quartiles", values = c("#696969", "darkgrey", "grey", "lightgrey")) 

pr <- pr + 
   annotate("text", x = rep(0, nrow(gender_counts)), y = gender_counts$GENDER, 
           label = paste("n =", gender_counts$count),
           hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 2, color = "black")

pr +
  annotate("text", x = mean(cleaned_data$READ) - 100, y = Inf, 
           label = paste("Mean:", round(mean(cleaned_data$READ), 0)),
           color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = 0.6, size = 3)

Plot 4 with Raincloud plots

code block 
gender_counts <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(count = n())


ggplot(cleaned_data, 
       aes(x = READ, 
           y = GENDER,
           color = GENDER)) +
  stat_halfeye(adjust = 0.5,
               justification = -0.2,
               .width = 0,
               point_colour = NA,
               height = 0.5) +
  geom_boxplot(width = .15,
               outlier.shape = NA,
               notch = TRUE) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#c73824", "#0477bf")) +
  stat_dots(side = "left", 
            justification = 1.1, 
            binwidth = 3,
            dotsize = 0.5,
            alpha = 0.4,
            aes(color = GENDER))  +
    stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun="mean",         
               colour ="black",        
               size=2) +
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") + 
    geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = -0.8, size = 3) + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE) +
  geom_text(data = gender_counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = GENDER, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000))

In the end, Plot 4 seemed the most aesthetically pleasing for Gender - we can see the distribution clearly with a modest left skew (reflected also in [2.1 Distribution Across Three Subjects - Mathematics, Reading and Science]) and interestingly, Female distribution is bimodal. We can also tell from the notched boxplot that it is statistically significant that Females have higher mean and median Reading scores than males. The histograms also show that top female outliers score higher than top male outliers while bottom male outliers score lower than bottom female outliers.

For Schools

The code chunk below shows four different recommended ways to improve the boxplot‚Äôs simplicity for 10 members of a group e.g. the top 5 and bottom 5 schools based on total scores of Mathematics, Reading and Science.

code block 
# Create a new variable to calculate total scores of READ, MATH, and SCIENCE
cleaned_data <- cleaned_data %>%
  mutate(TOTAL_SCORE = READ + MATH + SCIENCE)

# Calculate the mean total score for each school
school_totals <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(SCHOOLID) %>%
  summarize(MeanTotalScore = mean(TOTAL_SCORE, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = 'drop')

# Select the top 5 and bottom 5 schools
top_bottom_schools_total <- school_totals %>%
  arrange(MeanTotalScore) %>%
  slice(c(1:5, (n()-4):n())) %>%
  pull(SCHOOLID)

# Filter the original dataset to include only the selected schools
selected_school_data <- cleaned_data %>%
  filter(SCHOOLID %in% top_bottom_schools_total)

# Set the SCHOOLID as a factor ordered by the mean scores
selected_school_data <- selected_school_data %>%
  mutate(SCHOOLID = factor(SCHOOLID, levels = top_bottom_schools_total))

counts <- selected_school_data %>%
  group_by(SCHOOLID) %>%
  summarise(count = n())

Plot 1 with Notched Boxplots

code block 
p1  <- ggplot(selected_school_data, aes(x = READ, y = SCHOOLID)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch = TRUE) +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour = "black",     
               size = 2) + 
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ), median_score = median(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_score), color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = -0.8, size = 3) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))  + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE)  +
  geom_text(data = counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = SCHOOLID, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 1.2, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000))

p1 + annotate("rect", xmin = 545, xmax = Inf, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf,
           alpha = .05,fill = "#0477bf")

In the end, Plot 3 seemed the most aesthetically pleasing for SchoolIDs - there were 10 schools that were to be represented and the other plots seem to visually represent these 10 in a messy manner. It was hard for the eye to focus and draw any conclusions. The Ridgeline plot allowed the top 5 and bottom 5 to be seamlessly separated by the mean score for Reading and packed the schools together for easy comparability. It was easy to see that the top 5 schools and bottom 5 schools had variations between the groups and the bottom 5 performing schools had variations within their groups. Better performing schools also had higher student representation on average.

2.3.4 Makeover

The code chunk below prepares the individual histogram plots for each subject.

  • Reading vs Gender
  • Reading vs SES
  • Reading vs Schools
code block 
gender_counts <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(count = n())

# Calculate mean scores by gender
gender_means <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(MeanREADScore = mean(READ, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = 'drop')

# Determine the order based on mean scores
gender_order <- gender_means %>%
  arrange(MeanREADScore) %>%
  pull(GENDER)


readvsgen <-ggplot(cleaned_data, 
       aes(x = READ, 
           y = factor(GENDER, levels = gender_order),
           color = GENDER)) +
  stat_halfeye(adjust = 0.5,
               justification = -0.2,
               .width = 0,
               point_colour = NA,
               height = 0.5) +
  geom_boxplot(width = .15,
               outlier.shape = NA,
               notch = TRUE) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#c73824", "#0477bf")) +
  stat_dots(side = "left", 
            justification = 1.1, 
            binwidth = 3,
            dotsize = 0.5,
            alpha = 0.4,
            aes(color = GENDER))  +
    stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun="mean",         
               colour ="black",        
               size=2) +
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") + 
    geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("National Mean Reading Score:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = 0.85, size = 2.5) + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE) +
  geom_text(data = gender_counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = GENDER, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 2, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000))  +
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Reading Scores by Gender') 

readvsgen <- readvsgen + annotate("rect", xmin = 545, xmax = Inf, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf,
              alpha = 0.05, fill = "#0477bf")

readvsgen
code block 
readvsses <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=SES) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2")), hjust = -1, vjust =6.5, size = 2.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(-5, 5))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))   +
     geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") + 
    geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("National Mean Reading Score:", round(mean_score, 0))), color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust =0.85, size = 2.5) + 
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Reading Scores by Socioeconomic Status') 
readvsses <- readvsses + annotate("rect", xmin = 545, xmax = Inf, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf,
              alpha = 0.05, fill = "#0477bf")

readvsses
code block 
# Create a new variable to calculate total scores of READ, MATH, and SCIENCE
cleaned_data <- cleaned_data %>%
  mutate(TOTAL_SCORE = READ + MATH + SCIENCE)

# Calculate the mean total score for each school
school_totals <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(SCHOOLID) %>%
  summarize(MeanTotalScore = mean(TOTAL_SCORE, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = 'drop')

# Select the top 5 and bottom 5 schools
top_bottom_schools_total <- school_totals %>%
  arrange(MeanTotalScore) %>%
  slice(c(1:5, (n()-4):n())) %>%
  pull(SCHOOLID)

# Filter the original dataset to include only the selected schools
selected_school_data <- cleaned_data %>%
  filter(SCHOOLID %in% top_bottom_schools_total)

# Set the SCHOOLID as a factor ordered by the mean scores
selected_school_data <- selected_school_data %>%
  mutate(SCHOOLID = factor(SCHOOLID, levels = top_bottom_schools_total))

counts <- selected_school_data %>%
  group_by(SCHOOLID) %>%
  summarise(count = n())


readvssch <- ggplot(selected_school_data,
       aes(x = READ, 
           y = SCHOOLID, 
           fill = factor(after_stat(quantile))
           )) +
  stat_density_ridges(
    geom = "density_ridges_gradient",
    calc_ecdf = TRUE, 
    quantiles = 4,
    quantile_lines = TRUE) +
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_fill_manual(name = "Quartiles", values = c("#696969", "darkgrey", "grey", "lightgrey"))   +
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Reading Scores by Top 5 and Bottom 5 Schools') 

readvssch <- readvssch + annotate("rect", xmin = 545, xmax = Inf, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf,
           alpha = 0.05,fill = "#0477bf") 

readvssch <- readvssch + 
   annotate("text", x = rep(0, nrow(counts)), y = counts$SCHOOLID, 
           label = paste("n =", counts$count),
           hjust = 0.6, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black")

readvssch <- readvssch +
  annotate("text", x = mean(cleaned_data$READ) - 100, y = Inf, 
           label = paste("National Mean Reading Score:", round(mean(cleaned_data$READ), 0)),
           color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = 0.85, size = 2.5)

readvssch

2.3.5 Final Product: The relationships between Gender, SES and Schools with Reading scores

The code chunk below prepares the individual scatterplots for subject pairwise comparison as a composite figure.

code block 
patchwork <- readvsgen + readvsses + readvssch
patchwork <- patchwork + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "You will score higher on your reading if you are a girl and from a top 5 performing school.",
    subtitle = "Significant statistical differences in mean and median Reading scores between gender and top 5 and bottom 5 schools. \nTo our surprise, Socioeconomic differences did not have a correlation with Reading scores.",
    caption = "Data source: OECD PISA 2022",
    theme = theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 50))  
  )
patchwork & theme_fivethirtyeight(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor.x = element_line(linewidth = 0.2, linetype = 'solid', colour = "grey85"),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), axis.title=element_text(face = "bold", size=9))

3 Learning Points

This exercise gave me more scope on how to improve ways to visually represent data. My key learning points are:

  1. Studying how to improve plots and reading up how to do them is very beneficial. As someone with no design background and aphantasia, I cannot visualise how to improve data visualisations. Seeing others in action is necessary for me e.g. putting a shaded rectangle area to denote the upper section of the mean Reading score (see 2.3.4 Makeover) came from trying to improve boxplot (see Beyond the Trend: Storytelling with Scatter Plots).

  2. It is important to explore different ways to improve different types of plots - for e.g. the sections on Improving overplotting in scatterplots and Improving the visualisation of distribution in a boxplot. To improve a boxplot, I had Gender and Schools to plot against Reading scores. The improvement of Gender and Reading scores with a raincloud plot did not look good when applied to Schools and Reading scores, simply because Gender had 2 categories and I specified 10 schools for Schools. Hence, it is important to test out different visualisations to find what best fits your needs.

  3. Even though there can be trade-offs between aesthetics and clarity, I think a well-written title and subtitle would help to provide clarity that therefore allows room for aesthetics. An example is 2.2.5 Final Product: The relationships between Math, Reading and Science scores that did not have many explanatory elements in the plots but had a (hopefully) impactful title with a subtitle to provide context.

  4. Doing VAA is good to prevent yourself from being bored in hospital üôÉ.

# 1 Setting the scene

## 1.1 The Task

In this take-home exercise, you are required to:

-   select one of the Take-home Exercise 1 prepared by your classmate,

-   critic the submission in terms of clarity and aesthetics,

-   prepare a sketch for the alternative design by using the data visualisation design principles and best practices you had learned in Lesson 1 and 2, and

-   remake the original design by using ggplot2, ggplot2 extensions and tidyverse packages.

::: {.pastbox .past data-latex="code"}
#### **Remember Take-home Exercise 1**

The 2022 Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) data was released on December 5, 2022. PISA global education survey every three years to assess the education systems worldwide through testing 15 year old students in the subjects of mathematics, reading, and science.

In this take-home exercise, you are required to use appropriate **Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)** methods and **ggplot2** functions to reveal:

-   the distribution of Singapore students‚Äô performance in mathematics, reading, and science, and

-   the relationship between these performances with schools, gender and socioeconomic status (SES) of the students.

```{mermaid}
flowchart TB
  A[School] 
  B[SES]
  C[Gender]
  D[Reading Scores]
  E[Math Scores]
  F[Science Scores]
  
  D --> A
  D --> B
  D --> C
  E --> A
  E --> B
  E --> C
  F --> A
  F --> B
  F --> C
```
:::

## 1.2 Getting Started

### 1.2.1 Installing R packages and loading the dataset

The code chunk below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if the necessary packages are installed in the computer. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

```{r}
pacman::p_load(ggrepel, patchwork, 
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               tidyverse, kableExtra,
               haven, dplyr,
               ggdist, ggridges,
               colorspace, ggpmisc) 
```

The code chunk below reads the .rds file that contains cleaned data about students from Singapore.

```{r}
cleaned_data <-
  read_rds("data/cleaned_studata.rds")
```

# 2 Data Visualisations Makeover

The data visualisations were taken from [here](https://isss608-ay2024-rizfebriansyah.netlify.app/take-home_ex/take-home_ex01/take-home_ex01#reading-as-our-main-focus). I will be doing the makeover according to my favourite ggtheme [theme_fivethirtyeight()](https://abcnews.go.com/538)

## 2.1 **Distribution Across Three Subjects - Mathematics, Reading and Science**

::: grid
::: g-col-5
The author stated:

| *We will now do the plot for each respective subject. We will be doing a histogram to show the distribution across three subjects. The figure in the tabset below displays a composite of three histograms, seamlessly created using patchwork. This is specifically designed for merging separate ggplot2 graphs into a unified figure. The red dotted line indicates the mean.*

He later went on to conclude:

| *The histogram presented above offers a visual representation of the distribution of scores across three academic subjects: MATHEMATICS, READING and SCIENCE. The distribution pattern observed for each subject strongly aligns with the characteristics of **a normal distribution*** (bold my own)*.*
:::

::: g-col-7
![](images/distributions.png){width="500"}
:::
:::

| 
| *A normal distribution is characterised by a symmetrical bell-shaped curve, with the majority of data points clustering around the mean and gradually tapering off towards the extremes. In the context of academic performance, this implies that a significant proportion of students scored close to the average, while fewer students achieved scores either significantly above or below the mean.*

### 2.1.1 Own Thoughts

One key issue I want to highlight is the author's conclusion that the distributions of all three scores are **normal**. My own personal conclusion were the distributions were ***left-skewed***.

::: {.thinkbox .think data-latex="think"}
#### Visual Challenges

-   The visualisations did not clearly represent if the distributions were normal or left-skewed.
:::

### 2.1.2 Critique: Clarity and Aesthetics

This uncertainty could be due to how the data was visualised. By using the principles from [**A Layered Grammar of Graphics**](https://r4va.netlify.app/chap01),

::: grid
::: g-col-4
###### ![](images/clipboard-1344228557.png){width="32"} Level 7: Theme (Colour \| Space)

-   Aesthetics

    -   The blue and red, while to provide contrast, **does not blend well** with the other colours.
    -   Grid lines are soft and not distracting.

-   Clarity

    -   The patchwork neatly puts all the plots in one diagram but the dimensions are **not equally spaced** for each plot (it seems that Science scores are given more weightage than the rest).
:::

::: g-col-8
![](images/distribution1.gif){width="825"}
:::
:::

###### ![](images/clipboard-1690536157.png){width="40" height="40"}Level 7: Theme (Text)

-   Aesthetics

    -   There is too much **cluttered text**: the titles and axes labels are not well placed.
    -   *count* is not placed vertically: may not be necessary

-   Clarity

    -   There is **no overall main title or lead-in** to provide a context .e.g. the purpose and the story of the data visualisation.

    -   The titles are **repeated** e.g. Math scores and Mathematics.

    -   The axes are **not well-labelled** e.g. Mathematics as the x-axis.

    -   There is **no data source** caption included.

###### ![](images/clipboard-47177670.png){width="35" height="34"}Level 6: Coordinates \| Level 5: Statistics \| Level 3: Geometries \| Level 2: Aesthetics

-   Clarity

    -   The max labelled counts on the x-axis for the three plots are **not consistent** - 800 for Mathematics vs 750 for Reading and Science.

    -   The units of the y-axis for the three plots are **not consistent** - Math is 400, 600, 800 vs 200, 400, 600 and 800 for Reading and Science; and Science's x-axis starts at 200 while the rest appears to start at 0.

    -   The reference line (the mean) was very important for readability but still **failed to fully convey** if it was a normal or left-skewed distribution.

### 2.1.3 Sketch

These are my proposed main changes:

::: grid
::: g-col-5
![](images/clipboard-3895657816.png){width="38"} A well-crafted title and subtitle to provide context.

![](images/clipboard-556412521.png){width="39"} Add a median line together with the mean to clearly portray skewness.

![](images/clipboard-936539531.png){width="37" height="39"} Add a probability density plot to clearly visualise the distribution.

![](images/clipboard-2805879406.png){width="39"} Standardise the axes to improve comparability and interpretability.

![](images/clipboard-591484430.png){width="39" height="36"} Put the three plots side-by-side to improve readability.
:::

![](images/makeover1_sketch.png){width="500"}
:::

### 2.1.4 Makeover

The code chunk below prepares the individual histogram plots for each subject.

::: panel-tabset
## Mathematics

```{r}
math <- ggplot(data = cleaned_data, aes(x = MATH)) +
  geom_histogram(aes(y = after_stat(density)), bins = 20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color = "grey25", 
                 fill = "grey90",
                 linewidth = 0.3) +
  geom_density(linewidth = 0.2) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 0.0045))  +
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(MATH), median_score = median(MATH)),
             aes(xintercept = median_score), color = "#008FD5", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(MATH), median_score = median(MATH)),
             aes(x = median_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Median:", round(median_score, 0))),
             color = "#008FD5", vjust = 1, hjust = -0.55, size = 3) +
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(MATH), median_score = median(MATH)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_score), color = "#77AB43", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(MATH), median_score = median(MATH)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "#77AB43", vjust = 1, hjust = 0.55, size = 3) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100)) +
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Math scores') 
math

```

```{r}
             aes(x= READ)) +
```

```{r, fig.width= 12, fig.height = 6}
patchwork <- math + read + sci
patchwork <- patchwork + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Singapore students score exceptionally well in Maths, Reading and Science.",
    subtitle = "More than 50% of students have scores higher than the mean across the three PISA subjects.",
    caption = "Data source: OECD PISA 2022",
    theme = theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 50))  
  )
patchwork & theme_fivethirtyeight(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor.x = element_line(linewidth = 0.2, linetype = 'solid', colour = "grey85"),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), axis.title=element_text(face = "bold", size=9))
```

## 2.2 **Reading vs Mathematics**

::: grid
::: g-col-5
The author stated:

| *The scatterplot... illustrates a positive **correlation** between reading and mathematics values. As the reading values increase, so do the corresponding mathematics values. This relationship is further emphasised by the upward trend observed in the best fit line. The consistent increase in one variable is mirrored by a proportional increase in the other. In light of these findings, it can be confidently asserted that a positive connection exists, suggesting that engaging in reading contributes to enhanced performance in mathematics among students* (bold my own)*.*

### 2.2.1 Own Thoughts

1)  The author's intention of this data visualisation is a little **confusing** to me - why does the author only focus on one data visualisation with X = Reading and Y = Mathematics?
:::

::: g-col-7
![](images/clipboard-4197173982.png){width="499"}
:::

<!-- -->

2.  Bearing in mind that the plot intends to visualise the relationship between two continuous variables, I also automatically thought of the scatterplot. However, while it does visualise the relationship, the data visualisation **does not seem intuitive**, despite the presence of the linear model line.

::: {.thinkbox .think data-latex="think"}
#### Visual Challenges

-   How can we visually tease out the relationship of reading on the other subjects and vice versa?

-   The visualisation is messy due to overplotting - is there a better way to visualise the relationship between two continuous variables?

-   How can we improve the identification of correlation in a scatterplot?
:::

:::

#### Improving overplotting in scatterplots

According to [**A Complete Guide to Scatter Plots**](https://chartio.com/learn/charts/what-is-a-scatter-plot/)**,**

> *Overplotting is the case where data points overlap to a degree where we have difficulty seeing relationships between points and variables. It can be difficult to tell how densely-packed data points are when many of them are in a small area.*
>
> *There are a few common ways to alleviate this issue. One alternative is to sample only a subset of data points: a random selection of points should still give the general idea of the patterns in the full data. We can also change the form of the dots, adding transparency to allow for overlaps to be visible, or reducing point size so that fewer overlaps occur. As a third option, we might even choose a different chart type like the heatmap, where color indicates the number of points in each bin. Heatmaps in this use case are also known as 2-d histograms.*

[![Taken from \[A Complete Guide to Scatter Plots\](https://chartio.com/learn/charts/what-is-a-scatter-plot/)](images/clipboard-2059484608.png)](https://chartio.com/learn/charts/what-is-a-scatter-plot/)

The code chunk below shows four different recommended ways to address overplotting.

::: grid
::: g-col-6
**Plot 1 with sampled data (sample = 400)**

```{r, fig.width= 4.25, fig.height = 3}
# Set the seed for reproducibility
set.seed(123)

# Randomly select a sample of about 500 students
sampled_data <- cleaned_data %>% sample_n(400)

# Create the scatterplot with the sampled data
samplescatter <- ggplot(sampled_data, aes(x = READ, y = MATH)) +  
  geom_point() +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2"))) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                      minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))
samplescatter
```
:::

::: g-col-6
**Plot 2 with transparency (alpha = 0.03)**

```{r, fig.width= 4.25, fig.height = 3}
transscatter <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=MATH) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2"))) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))

transscatter
```
:::
:::

::: grid
::: g-col-6
**Plot 3 with hexagon binning (bins = 25)**

```{r, fig.width= 5, fig.height = 3}
hexscatter <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=MATH) ) +
  geom_hex(bins = 25, color = "white", alpha = 0.6) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low="#008FD5",high="black")+
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2"))) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "black", alpha = 0.4)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))

hexscatter
```
:::

::: g-col-6
**Plot 4 with 2D Histogram (bins = 25)**

```{r, fig.width= 5, fig.height = 3}
twodscatter <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=MATH) ) +
  geom_bin2d(bins = 25, color = "white",alpha = 0.6) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low="#008FD5",high="black")+
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2"))) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "black", alpha = 0.4)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))
 
twodscatter
```
:::
:::

In the end, Plot 2 seemed the most aesthetically pleasing - since the scatterplot's intention is to convey that there is a correlation between Reading and Math scores, and given that most scores cluster in the middle of the cloud, it appeared that binning or gradient colours made it messier.

### 2.2.4 Makeover

The code chunk below prepares the individual histogram plots for each subject.

::: panel-tabset
## Reading vs Mathematics

```{r}
# Calculate midpoints
mean_math <- mean(cleaned_data$MATH)

readvsmath <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=MATH) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2")), hjust = -0.45, vjust = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))  +
 ylab('Math Scores') + xlab('Reading Scores') 

readvsmath
```

## Reading vs Science

```{r}
readvssci <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=SCIENCE) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2")), hjust = -0.51, vjust = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))   +
 ylab('Science Scores') + xlab('Reading Scores') 
readvssci

```

## Mathematics vs Science

```{r}
mathvssci <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=MATH, y=SCIENCE) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2")), hjust = -0.42, vjust = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(0, 1000))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))   +
 ylab('Science Scores') + xlab('Math Scores')
```
