### 2.2.5 Final Product: The relationships between Math, Reading and Science scores

The code chunk below prepares the individual scatterplots for subject pairwise comparison as a composite figure.

```{r, fig.width= 12, fig.height = 6}
patchwork <- readvsmath + readvssci + mathvssci
patchwork <- patchwork + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "The higher you score in one subject, the more likely you will score as well as in the other subjects.",
    subtitle = "Strong positive linear relationships between Math, Reading and Science scores.\nThis is especially true in Math and Science scores that have the strongest correlation.",
    caption = "Data source: OECD PISA 2022",
    theme = theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 50))  
  )
patchwork & theme_fivethirtyeight(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor.x = element_line(linewidth = 0.2, linetype = 'solid', colour = "grey85"),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), axis.title=element_text(face = "bold", size=9))
```

## 2.3 **‚ÄúReading‚Äù as our main focus**

As mentioned in the previous section, the author is focusing on Reading scores as

> *\[W\]e assert that prioritising reading over mathematics is essential for enhanced performance in science learning.*
>
> *Henceforth, our focus will be exclusively on reading, considering it as the primary driver for improved achievement in other subjects, including Mathematics and Science.*

The author took this perspective because:

> *With reference to this research paper titled ‚ÄòReading matters more than mathematics in science learning: an analysis of the relationship between student achievement in reading, mathematics, and science‚Äô by Yuanze Zhu, the results revealed that proficiency in reading and mathematics strongly correlated with science achievement, with reading exerting a more substantial influence than mathematics.*

The author built three different plots to uncover the relationship between Gender, Socioeconomic status (SES) and Schools; and Reading scores.

::: panel-tabset
## Gender

A boxplot was used to visualise the differences in reading scores between females and males.

![](images/clipboard-3040735814.png){width="501"}

## Socioeconomic status

A scatterplot was used to derive any relationship between Reading scores and one's socioeconomic status (SES).

![](images/clipboard-1717027209.png){width="501"}

## Schools

A boxplot was used to visualise the differences in reading scores amongst the top 5 heavily represented schools (those who had the most students participating) in PISA.

![](images/clipboard-2948822257.png){width="501"}
:::

### 2.3.1 Own Thoughts

1)  I find it **confusing** to have three separate plots - I think we can group all plots together as the common variable is Reading scores.

2)  I think the choice of using the top 5 heavily represented schools is **not meaningful**. Using the label "top 5" is more traditionally associated with performance, rather than size of representation.

::: {.thinkbox .think data-latex="think"}
#### Visual Challenges

-   How can we visually tease out the relationship of the three independent variables on reading scores?

-   Boxplots limit our understanding on the shape of distribution, modality and skewness. How can we improve the readability of boxplots?

-   How can we improve SchoolIDs as a meaningful label and visually represent them?
:::

As scatterplots have been critiqued and explored in the previous section of \[2.2 Reading vs Mathematics\], I will makeover the Reading scores vs ESCS in the same way, while flipping the X- and Y- axis.

### 2.3.2 Critique: Clarity and Aesthetics

In this section, I will be critiquing the use of boxplots to visually represent the relationships between Gender and Schools; and Reading scores. By using the principles from [**A Layered Grammar of Graphics**](https://r4va.netlify.app/chap01),

::: grid
::: g-col-4
###### ![](images/clipboard-1344228557.png){width="32"} Level 7: Theme (Colour \| Space)

-   Aesthetics

    -   The choice of black and grey was in line with previous data visualisations, providing consistency.

    -   The choice of a red dot (mean) on black provided contrast, but the colours were **jarring** and not in line with a theme.

    -   Grid lines are soft and not distracting.
:::

::: g-col-8
![](images/boxplots.gif){width="825"}
:::
:::

-   Clarity

    -   It was **confusing** to separate the plots - a story about effects on Reading scores would be better visualised if the plots were together.

###### ![](images/clipboard-1690536157.png){width="40" height="40"}Level 7: Theme (Text)

-   Aesthetics

    -   Axes are well-labelled so we can immediately see what relationship (X- and Y- variables) the plot is visualising.

-   Clarity

    -   There is **no overall main title or lead-in** to provide a context .e.g. the purpose and the story of the data visualisation.

    -   There is **no data source** caption included.

    -   CNTSCHID as a label is not **meaningful**.

###### ![](images/clipboard-47177670.png){width="38" height="38"}and ![](images/clipboard-1102525892.png){width="36"} Level 6: Coordinates \| Level 5: Statistics \| Level 3: Geometries \| Level 2: Aesthetics

-   Aesthetics

    -   While boxplots give an excellent summary of the statistics, it looks very **plain**; especially since Males and Females have the same colour or all the schools presented have the same colour.

-   Clarity

    -   Boxplots are good to compare between multiple groups e.g. between Males and Females and between schools.

    -   The scales on the x-axis and y-axis are consistent - 800 for Reading scores, but may be too **limited** at 800 and result in outliers been cut off.

    -   Clearly visualised some skewness with the use of the mean (red dot) and the outliers but **hard to compare** with other members of the group.

    -   The order of groups is also **confusing** - in the Schools boxplot, there is no inherent order and thus difficult to compare between schools.

    -   Boxplots do not allow us to observe the detailed shape of distribution of each groups - it was **hard to see** if the distribution was truly skewed.

    -   The boxplots **cannot be intuitively interpreted** as they are not annotated with the sample population size, mean and median values.

    -   SchoolIDs and their label CNTSCHID **poorly represents** the top 5 heavily represented schools in the sample. It does not allow for easy interpretability.

### 2.3.3 Sketch

These are my proposed main changes:

::: grid
::: g-col-5
![](images/clipboard-3895657816.png){width="38"} A well-crafted title and subtitle to provide context.

![](images/clipboard-556412521.png){width="39"} Explore different ways (refer to section below) to improve the simplicity of the boxplot.

![](images/clipboard-936539531.png){width="37" height="39"} Add text annotations such as the sample size to the boxplots.

![](images/clipboard-2805879406.png){width="39"} Recreate CNTSCHID by using top 5 and bottom 5 performing schools in Reading scores.

![](images/clipboard-591484430.png){width="39" height="36"} Makeover the scatterplot of ESCS vs Reading scores using the above section's scatterplot design.

![](images/clipboard-2374361642.png){width="39"} Put the plots side-by-side to improve interpretability and readability for Reading scores.
:::

::: g-col-7
![](images/makeover3_sketch.png){width="500"}
:::
:::

#### Improving the visualisation of distribution in a boxplot

According to [**A Complete Guide to Scatter Plots**](https://chartio.com/learn/charts/what-is-a-scatter-plot/), [**The Box Plot: A Simple but Informative Visualization**](https://medium.com/analytics-vidhya/the-box-plot-a-simple-but-informative-visualization-cacc20d9ff25#:~:text=How%20can%20a%20box%20plot,limitation%20of%20the%20pie%20chart.)and [**9  Visualising Distribution**](https://r4va.netlify.app/chap09), there are four ways to improve the simplicity of the boxplot by using:t

1.  Notches in boxplots

> *Notches are used to show the most likely values expected for the median when the data represents a sample. When a comparison is made between groups, you can tell if the difference between medians are statistically significant based on if their ranges overlap. If any of the notch areas overlap, then we can‚Äôt say that the medians are statistically different; if they do not have overlap, then we can have good confidence that the true medians differ.* [**A Complete Guide to Scatter Plots**](https://chartio.com/learn/charts/what-is-a-scatter-plot/)

2.  Violin plots

> *In a violin plot, each group‚Äôs distribution is indicated by a density curve. In a density curve, each data point does not fall into a single bin like in a histogram, but instead contributes a small volume of area to the total distribution. Violin plots are a compact way of comparing distributions between groups. Often, additional markings are added to the violin plot to also provide the standard box plot information, but this can make the resulting plot noisier to read.* [**A Complete Guide to Scatter Plots**](https://chartio.com/learn/charts/what-is-a-scatter-plot/)

3.  Ridgeline plots

> *Ridgeline plot (sometimes called Joyplot) is a data visualisation technique for revealing the distribution of a numeric value for several groups. Distribution can be represented using histograms or density plots, all aligned to the same horizontal scale and presented with a slight overlap.* [**9  Visualising Distribution**](https://r4va.netlify.app/chap09)

4.  Raincloud plots

> *Raincloud Plot is a data visualisation techniques that produces a half-density to a distribution plot. It gets the name because the density plot is in the shape of a ‚Äúraincloud‚Äù. The raincloud (half-density) plot enhances the traditional box-plot by highlighting multiple modalities (an indicator that groups may exist). The boxplot does not show where densities are clustered, but the raincloud plot does!* [**9  Visualising Distribution**](https://r4va.netlify.app/chap09)

##### For Gender

The code chunk below shows four different recommended ways to improve the boxplot's simplicity for two categories e.g. males and females.

::: grid
::: g-col-6
**Plot 1 with Notched Boxplots**

```{r, fig.width= 5, fig.height = 4}

gender_counts <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(count = n())

ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x = READ, y = GENDER, color = GENDER)) +  
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#c73824", "#0477bf")) +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun="mean",         
               colour ="black",     
               size=2) + 
     geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = -0.8, size = 3) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                      minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))  + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE)  +
  geom_text(data = gender_counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = GENDER, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000)) 

```
:::

::: g-col-6
**Plot 2 with Violin + Notched Boxplots**

```{r, fig.width= 5, fig.height = 4}

gender_counts <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(count = n())

ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x = READ, y = GENDER, color = GENDER)) +  
    geom_violin(aes(fill = GENDER), size = 0.6, alpha = 0.4, linewidth = 0) +
  geom_boxplot(width= 0.4, outlier.colour = "grey20", outlier.size = 1, 
               outlier.alpha = 0.3, notch = TRUE) +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun="mean",         
               colour ="black",        
               size=2) +  
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = -0.8, size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#c73824", "#0477bf")) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                      minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100)) + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE)  +
  geom_text(data = gender_counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = GENDER, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000))
```
:::
:::

::: grid
::: g-col-6
**Plot 3 with Ridgeline plots**

```{r, fig.width= 5, fig.height = 4}

pr <- ggplot(cleaned_data,
       aes(x = READ, 
           y = GENDER, 
           fill = factor(after_stat(quantile))
           )) +
  stat_density_ridges(
    geom = "density_ridges_gradient",
    calc_ecdf = TRUE, 
    quantiles = 4,
    quantile_lines = TRUE) +
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_fill_manual(name = "Quartiles", values = c("#696969", "darkgrey", "grey", "lightgrey")) 

pr <- pr + 
   annotate("text", x = rep(0, nrow(gender_counts)), y = gender_counts$GENDER, 
           label = paste("n =", gender_counts$count),
           hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 2, color = "black")

pr +
  annotate("text", x = mean(cleaned_data$READ) - 100, y = Inf, 
           label = paste("Mean:", round(mean(cleaned_data$READ), 0)),
           color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = 0.6, size = 3)
```
:::

::: g-col-6
**Plot 4 with Raincloud plots**

```{r, fig.width= 5, fig.height = 4}

gender_counts <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(count = n())


ggplot(cleaned_data, 
       aes(x = READ, 
           y = GENDER,
           color = GENDER)) +
  stat_halfeye(adjust = 0.5,
               justification = -0.2,
               .width = 0,
               point_colour = NA,
               height = 0.5) +
  geom_boxplot(width = .15,
               outlier.shape = NA,
               notch = TRUE) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#c73824", "#0477bf")) +
  stat_dots(side = "left", 
            justification = 1.1, 
            binwidth = 3,
            dotsize = 0.5,
            alpha = 0.4,
            aes(color = GENDER))  +
    stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun="mean",         
               colour ="black",        
               size=2) +
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") + 
    geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = -0.8, size = 3) + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE) +
  geom_text(data = gender_counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = GENDER, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000))
```
:::
:::

In the end, Plot 4 seemed the most aesthetically pleasing for Gender - we can see the distribution clearly with a modest left skew (reflected also in \[2.1 Distribution Across Three Subjects - Mathematics, Reading and Science\]) and interestingly, Female distribution is bimodal. We can also tell from the notched boxplot that it is statistically significant that Females have higher mean and median Reading scores than males. The histograms also show that top female outliers score higher than top male outliers while bottom male outliers score lower than bottom female outliers.

##### For Schools

The code chunk below shows four different recommended ways to improve the boxplot's simplicity for 10 members of a group e.g. the top 5 and bottom 5 schools based on total scores of Mathematics, Reading and Science.

```{r}
# Create a new variable to calculate total scores of READ, MATH, and SCIENCE
cleaned_data <- cleaned_data %>%
  mutate(TOTAL_SCORE = READ + MATH + SCIENCE)

# Calculate the mean total score for each school
school_totals <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(SCHOOLID) %>%
  summarize(MeanTotalScore = mean(TOTAL_SCORE, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = 'drop')

# Select the top 5 and bottom 5 schools
top_bottom_schools_total <- school_totals %>%
  arrange(MeanTotalScore) %>%
  slice(c(1:5, (n()-4):n())) %>%
  pull(SCHOOLID)

# Filter the original dataset to include only the selected schools
selected_school_data <- cleaned_data %>%
  filter(SCHOOLID %in% top_bottom_schools_total)

# Set the SCHOOLID as a factor ordered by the mean scores
selected_school_data <- selected_school_data %>%
  mutate(SCHOOLID = factor(SCHOOLID, levels = top_bottom_schools_total))

counts <- selected_school_data %>%
  group_by(SCHOOLID) %>%
  summarise(count = n())
```

::: grid
::: g-col-6
**Plot 1 with Notched Boxplots**

```{r, fig.width= 12, fig.height = 10}

p1  <- ggplot(selected_school_data, aes(x = READ, y = SCHOOLID)) +
  geom_boxplot(notch = TRUE) +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour = "black",     
               size = 2) + 
  geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ), median_score = median(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_score), color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +  
  geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("Mean:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = -0.8, size = 3) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))  + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE)  +
  geom_text(data = counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = SCHOOLID, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 1.2, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000))

p1 + annotate("rect", xmin = 545, xmax = Inf, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf,
           alpha = .05,fill = "#0477bf")

```

```{r, fig.width= 12, fig.height = 10}
              alpha = 0.05, fill = "#0477bf")
```
:::
:::

In the end, Plot 3 seemed the most aesthetically pleasing for SchoolIDs - there were 10 schools that were to be represented and the other plots seem to visually represent these 10 in a messy manner. It was hard for the eye to focus and draw any conclusions. The Ridgeline plot allowed the top 5 and bottom 5 to be seamlessly separated by the mean score for Reading and packed the schools together for easy comparability. It was easy to see that the top 5 schools and bottom 5 schools had variations between the groups and the bottom 5 performing schools had variations within their groups. Better performing schools also had higher student representation on average.

### 2.3.4 Makeover

The code chunk below prepares the individual histogram plots for each subject.

::: panel-tabset
## Reading vs Gender

```{r}
gender_counts <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(count = n())

# Calculate mean scores by gender
gender_means <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(GENDER) %>%
  summarise(MeanREADScore = mean(READ, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = 'drop')

# Determine the order based on mean scores
gender_order <- gender_means %>%
  arrange(MeanREADScore) %>%
  pull(GENDER)


readvsgen <-ggplot(cleaned_data, 
       aes(x = READ, 
           y = factor(GENDER, levels = gender_order),
           color = GENDER)) +
  stat_halfeye(adjust = 0.5,
               justification = -0.2,
               .width = 0,
               point_colour = NA,
               height = 0.5) +
  geom_boxplot(width = .15,
               outlier.shape = NA,
               notch = TRUE) +
  scale_color_manual(values=c("#c73824", "#0477bf")) +
  stat_dots(side = "left", 
            justification = 1.1, 
            binwidth = 3,
            dotsize = 0.5,
            alpha = 0.4,
            aes(color = GENDER))  +
    stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun="mean",         
               colour ="black",        
               size=2) +
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") + 
    geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("National Mean Reading Score:", round(mean_score, 0))),
             color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = 0.85, size = 2.5) + 
  guides(color = FALSE, fill = FALSE) +
  geom_text(data = gender_counts,
            aes(x = 0, y = GENDER, label = paste("n =", count)),
            hjust = 0.3, vjust = 0.45, size = 2, color = "black") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000))  +
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Reading Scores by Gender') 

readvsgen <- readvsgen + annotate("rect", xmin = 545, xmax = Inf, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf,
              alpha = 0.05, fill = "#0477bf")

readvsgen
```

## Reading vs SES

```{r}
readvsses <- ggplot(cleaned_data, aes(x=READ, y=SES) ) +  
  geom_point(alpha = 0.03) +
  stat_poly_eq(use_label(c("eq", "R2")), hjust = -1, vjust =6.5, size = 2.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, linewidth = 0.2, color = "#008FD5", alpha = 0.3)  +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 1000), ylim = c(-5, 5))  +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 200),  
                     minor_breaks = seq(0, 1000, by = 100))   +
     geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") + 
    geom_text(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_score = mean(READ)),
             aes(x = mean_score - 100, y = Inf, label = paste("National Mean Reading Score:", round(mean_score, 0))), color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust =0.85, size = 2.5) + 
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Reading Scores by Socioeconomic Status') 
readvsses <- readvsses + annotate("rect", xmin = 545, xmax = Inf, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf,
              alpha = 0.05, fill = "#0477bf")

readvsses

```

## Reading vs Schools

```{r}
# Create a new variable to calculate total scores of READ, MATH, and SCIENCE
cleaned_data <- cleaned_data %>%
  mutate(TOTAL_SCORE = READ + MATH + SCIENCE)

# Calculate the mean total score for each school
school_totals <- cleaned_data %>%
  group_by(SCHOOLID) %>%
  summarize(MeanTotalScore = mean(TOTAL_SCORE, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = 'drop')

# Select the top 5 and bottom 5 schools
top_bottom_schools_total <- school_totals %>%
  arrange(MeanTotalScore) %>%
  slice(c(1:5, (n()-4):n())) %>%
  pull(SCHOOLID)

# Filter the original dataset to include only the selected schools
selected_school_data <- cleaned_data %>%
  filter(SCHOOLID %in% top_bottom_schools_total)

# Set the SCHOOLID as a factor ordered by the mean scores
selected_school_data <- selected_school_data %>%
  mutate(SCHOOLID = factor(SCHOOLID, levels = top_bottom_schools_total))

counts <- selected_school_data %>%
  group_by(SCHOOLID) %>%
  summarise(count = n())


readvssch <- ggplot(selected_school_data,
       aes(x = READ, 
           y = SCHOOLID, 
           fill = factor(after_stat(quantile))
           )) +
  stat_density_ridges(
    geom = "density_ridges_gradient",
    calc_ecdf = TRUE, 
    quantiles = 4,
    quantile_lines = TRUE) +
   geom_vline(data = cleaned_data %>%
               summarize(mean_value = mean(READ)),
             aes(xintercept = mean_value),
             color = "black", linetype = "dashed") +
  scale_fill_manual(name = "Quartiles", values = c("#696969", "darkgrey", "grey", "lightgrey"))   +
 ylab(NULL) + xlab('Distribution of Reading Scores by Top 5 and Bottom 5 Schools') 

readvssch <- readvssch + annotate("rect", xmin = 545, xmax = Inf, ymin = -Inf, ymax = Inf,
           alpha = 0.05,fill = "#0477bf") 

readvssch <- readvssch + 
   annotate("text", x = rep(0, nrow(counts)), y = counts$SCHOOLID, 
           label = paste("n =", counts$count),
           hjust = 0.6, vjust = 0.45, size = 3, color = "black")

readvssch <- readvssch +
  annotate("text", x = mean(cleaned_data$READ) - 100, y = Inf, 
           label = paste("National Mean Reading Score:", round(mean(cleaned_data$READ), 0)),
           color = "black", vjust = 2, hjust = 0.85, size = 2.5)

readvssch
```
:::

### 2.3.5 Final Product: The relationships between Gender, SES and Schools with Reading scores

The code chunk below prepares the individual scatterplots for subject pairwise comparison as a composite figure.

```{r, fig.width= 12, fig.height = 6}
patchwork <- readvsgen + readvsses + readvssch
patchwork <- patchwork + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "You will score higher on your reading if you are a girl and from a top 5 performing school.",
    subtitle = "Significant statistical differences in mean and median Reading scores between gender and top 5 and bottom 5 schools. \nTo our surprise, Socioeconomic differences did not have a correlation with Reading scores.",
    caption = "Data source: OECD PISA 2022",
    theme = theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 50))  
  )
patchwork & theme_fivethirtyeight(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor.x = element_line(linewidth = 0.2, linetype = 'solid', colour = "grey85"),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"), axis.title=element_text(face = "bold", size=9))
```

# 3 Learning Points

This exercise gave me more scope on how to improve ways to visually represent data. My key learning points are:

1.  Studying how to improve plots and reading up how to do them is very beneficial. As someone with no design background and aphantasia, I cannot visualise how to improve data visualisations. Seeing others in action is necessary for me e.g. putting a shaded rectangle area to denote the upper section of the mean Reading score (see [2.3.4 Makeover]) came from trying to improve boxplot (see [Beyond the Trend: Storytelling with Scatter Plots](https://www.anyamemensah.com/blog/storytelling-with-scatter-plots)).

2.  It is important to explore different ways to improve different types of plots - for e.g. the sections on [Improving overplotting in scatterplots] and [Improving the visualisation of distribution in a boxplot]. To improve a boxplot, I had Gender and Schools to plot against Reading scores. The improvement of Gender and Reading scores with a raincloud plot did not look good when applied to Schools and Reading scores, simply because Gender had 2 categories and I specified 10 schools for Schools. Hence, it is important to test out different visualisations to find what best fits your needs.

3.  Even though there can be trade-offs between aesthetics and clarity, I think a well-written title and subtitle would help to provide clarity that therefore allows room for aesthetics. An example is [2.2.5 Final Product: The relationships between Math, Reading and Science scores] that did not have many explanatory elements in the plots but had a (hopefully) impactful title with a subtitle to provide context.

4.  Doing VAA is good to prevent yourself from being bored in hospital üôÉ.
